'en', 'pageNumber': 0, 'inputText': 'HONOLULU (HawaiiNewsNow) - From the U.S. Congress to the Hawaii State Capitol, lawmakers are racing to come up with new rules to control artificial technology. In the islands, there’s a push to force political campaigns to tell voters when they use fake imagery. Essentially, Hawaii lawmakers want to keep AI-generated images out of politics. State Rep. Trish La Chica, who represents parts of Central Oahu, is introducing legislation to require campaigns to label any use of artificial intelligence starting 90 days before any primary or general election. View the proposed bill by clicking here. “As a young freshman representative, I see AI being used and spreading like wildfire. And many of those are fraudulent,” said La Chica. “You could easily be scrolling through Facebook and then see a candidate running for office condoning police brutality or saying something or being somewhere they weren’t.” At least a dozen states, including California, Michigan and Minnesota, already have laws restricting AI. “Here in Hawaii, some of these elections win by slim margins,” Rep. La Chica said. “AI can easily tank someone’s election.” Wayne Buente, a professor in the University of Hawaii School of Communications and Information, says the concerns are real. “It does look very convincing, but that is the state of technology at this time,” said Buente. “Right now I believe the challenge is this technology is moving far faster than the laws and policies that can place breaks, guardrails on it.” Buente says as AI develops, the best antidote may not be new laws but public vigilance. “It does put the onus on people themselves to do their best to use third-party fact checkers. Check your sources. Really do your homework on the content you’re seeing.” Copyright 2024 Hawaii News Now. All rights reserved.'}]
